sen.j: 井上 源三郎（いのうえ げんざぶろう、文政12年3月1日 (旧暦)（1829年4月4日） - 慶応4年1月5日 (旧暦)（1868年1月29日）は、新選組六番隊組長。
sen.e: Genzaburo INOUE (April 4, 1829, which was March 1 according to the old calendar - January 29, 1868, which was January 5, according to the old calendar) was a leader of the 6th Group of the Shinsengumi (a group who guarded Kyoto during the end of Tokugawa Shogunate).

Genzaburo INOUE (April 4, 1829, which was March 1 according to the old calendar - January 29, 1868, which was January 5, according to the old calendar) was a leader of the 6th Group of the Shinsengumi (a group who guarded Kyoto during the end of the Tokugawa Shogunate).
Genzaburo INOUE (April 4, 1829 - January 29, 1868) was a leader of the 6th Group of the Shinsengumi (a group who guarded Kyoto during the end of the Tokugawa Shogunate).

sen.j: 諱は一武（かずたけ）。
sen.e: His imina (personal name) was Kazutake
His imina (personal name) was Kazutake
His imina (personal name) was Kazutake.

tit.cmt: 統一リストに従って修正

sen.j: 生真面目で誠実な人物だと伝わっている。
sen.e: He was said to have been very serious and sincere. When
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: He was said to have been very serious and sincere. When
He was said to have been very serious and sincere.

sen.j: 壬生で子供たちと遊んでいた沖田総司が通りがかりの源三郎に声をかけた。
sen.e: There is a story told about Genzaburo passing by the street in Mibu, where Soshi OKITA was playing with children.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: There is a story told about Genzaburo passing by the street in Mibu, where Soshi OKITA was playing with children.
There is a story told about Genzaburo passing by the street in Mibu, where Soshi OKITA was playing with children.

sen.j: 「また稽古ですか、熱心ですね」と声をかけると、「わかっているなら稽古をしたら良いのに」とたしなめたというエピソードが残っている。
sen.e: Soshi asked, "Are you going to practice?" and said, "You are very diligent," Genzaburo replied "You should practice, too."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Soshi asked, "Are you going to practice?" and said, "You are very diligent," Genzaburo replied "You should practice, too."
Soshi asked, 'Are you going to practice?' and said, 'You are very diligent,' Genzaburo replied 'You should practice, too.'

sen.j: また八木為三郎は「井上はその頃四十歳くらいで、ひどく無口な、それでいて非常に人の良い人でした」といった意味のことを語っている。
sen.e: Tamesaburo YAGI said of Genzaburo that "Inoue was about 40 years old at the time, very quiet but a good-natured person."
Tamesaburo YAGI said of Genzaburo that "Inoue was about 40 years old at the time, very quiet but a good-natured person."
Tamesaburo YAGI said of Genzaburo that 'Inoue was about 40 years old at the time, very quiet but a good-natured person.'

sen.j: 無口だが温厚な性格で、若い隊士からの人望も厚かったという。
sen.e: He was quiet but warm and was respected by the young Shinsengumi members.
He was quiet but warm and was respected by the young Shinsengumi members.
He was quiet but warm and was respected by the young Shinsengumi members.

sen.j: 一方で頑固な面もあり、一度言い出すとテコでも動かないところがあったともいう。
sen.e: On the other hand, he was very stubborn, and he would never go back on his word.
On the other hand, he was very stubborn, and he would never go back on his word.
On the other hand, he was very stubborn, and he would never go back on his word.

sen.j: 武州日野市日野宿北原（ひのじゅくきたばら／現在の東京都日野市日野本町）に八王子千人同心世話役の井上藤左衛門（松五郎とも）の三男として生まれる。
sen.e: Genzaburo was born in Hinojukukitabara, Bushuhino City (currently Hinohonmachi Town, Hino City, Tokyo) the third son of Tozaemon INOUE (also called Matsugoro), who was steward for Hachioji Sennin Doshin (junior officials in Hachioji).

Genzaburo was born in Hinojukukitabara, Bushuhino City (currently Hinohonmachi Town, Hino City, Tokyo) the third son of Tozaemon INOUE (also called Matsugoro), who was steward for Hachioji Sennin Doshin (junior officials in Hachioji).

Genzaburo was born in Hinojukukitabara, Bushuhino City (currently Hinohon-machi, Hino City, Tokyo) the third son of Tozaemon INOUE (also called Matsugoro), who was steward for Hachioji Sennin Doshin (junior officials in Hachioji).

sen.j: 兄・井上松五郎は千人同心。
sen.e: His older brother was Matsugoro INOUE, a member of Sennin Doshin (junior officials).
His older brother was Matsugoro INOUE, a member of Sennin Doshin (junior officials).
His older brother was Matsugoro INOUE, a member of Sennin Doshin (junior officials).

sen.j: 弘化4年（1847年）頃、源三郎は当時多摩郡に広まりつつあった天然理心流剣術の三代目宗家・近藤周助に入門する。
sen.e: In about 1847, he studied under Shusuke KONDO, the third generation grand master for Tennenrishinryu swordmanship, that was spreading around Tama District.
In about 1847, he studied under Shusuke KONDO, the third generation grand master for Tennenrishinryu swordmanship, that was spreading around Tama District.
In about 1847, he studied under Shusuke KONDO, the third generation grand master for Tennenrishinryu swordsmanship, that was spreading around Tama District.

sen.j: 土方歳三の義兄、佐藤彦五郎が天然理心流の出稽古用に設けた道場で土方らと共に稽古に励んだ。
sen.e: He trained along with Toshizo HIJIKATA at a Tennenrishinryu training hall that was set up by Hijikata's step-brother, Hikojiro SATO.
He trained along with Toshizo HIJIKATA at a Tennenrishinryu training hall that was set up by Hijikata's step-brother, Hikojiro SATO.
He trained along with Toshizo HIJIKATA at a Tennenrishinryu training hall that was set up by Hijikata's step-brother, Hikogoro SATO.

sen.j: また、近藤勇の兄弟子でもあった。
sen.e: He was also a senior fellow pupil of Isami KONDO.
He was also a senior fellow pupil of Isami KONDO.
He was also a senior fellow pupil of Isami KONDO.

sen.j: 彼らとは、この時期以来親交を深めていったとされる。
sen.e: He built friendships with them from this time.
He built friendships with them from this time.
He built friendships with them from this time.

sen.j: 万延元年（1860年）、免許皆伝を受ける。
sen.e: In 1860, he received his Menkyo-kaiden (full proficiency).
In 1860, he received his Menkyo-kaiden (full proficiency).
In 1860, he received his Menkyo-kaiden (full proficiency).

sen.j: 文久2年2月、清河八郎献策の浪士組に近藤・土方らと参加。
sen.e: In 1862, he joined the Roshigumi (an organization of masterless samurai) recommended by Hachiro KIYOKAWA, along with Kondo and Hijikata.
In 1862, he joined the Roshigumi (an organization of masterless samurai) recommended by Hachiro KIYOKAWA, along with Kondo and Hijikata.
In March 1862, he joined the Roshigumi (an organization of masterless samurai) recommended by Hachiro KIYOKAWA, along with Kondo and Hijikata.

sen.j: 文久3年9月の芹沢鴨一派の粛清後は副長助勤となり、以後、新選組の幹部であり続ける。
sen.e: In September 1963, after the purging of the Kamo SERIZAWA group, he was appointed Fukucho jokin (assistant vice commander), and, thereafter, remained executive officer of the Shinsengumi.
In September 1963, after the purging of the Kamo SERIZAWA group, he was appointed Fukucho jokin (assistant vice commander), and, thereafter, remained executive officer of the Shinsengumi.
In October 1963, after the purging of the Kamo SERIZAWA group, he was appointed Fukucho jokin (assistant vice commander), and, thereafter, remained executive officer of the Shinsengumi.

sen.j: 同郷・同門の局長近藤や副長土方をよく補佐し、お互いに絶大な信頼で結ばれていた。
sen.e: He supported Kondo and Hijikata, Head and Deputy Head, who came from the same home and training hall, and there was strong trust among them.
He supported Kondo and Hijikata, Head and Deputy Head, who came from the same home and training hall, and there was strong trust among them.
He supported Kondo and Hijikata, Head and Deputy Head, who came from the same home and training hall, and there was strong trust among them.

sen.j: 隊内では主として対外的な職務や要人の接待などの総務を担当。
sen.e: He was in charge, dealing mainly with outside matters and entertaining important figures.
He was in charge, dealing mainly with outside matters and entertaining important figures.
He was in charge, dealing mainly with outside matters and entertaining important figures.

sen.j: 元治元年6月の池田屋事件では土方隊の支隊を指揮し、近藤隊が斬り込んだ知らせを受けると十人の部下と池田屋に入り、八人の浪士を捕縛するなど活躍した。
sen.e: In June 1864, during the Ikedaya Incident, he led a squad of the Hijikata troop, and upon hearing that the Kondo troop had entered by force, he led 10 of his men and captured 8 samurai.
In June 1864, during the Ikedaya Incident, he led a squad of the Hijikata troop, and upon hearing that the Kondo troop had entered by force, he led 10 of his men and captured 8 samurai.
In July 1864, during the Ikedaya Incident, he led a squad of the Hijikata troop, and upon hearing that the Kondo troop had entered by force, he led 10 of his men and captured 8 samurai.

sen.j: 剣豪揃いの新選組にあって、源三郎の剣は目立たなかったが、自分の立場をよく理解し、落ち度無く任務を遂行する人物であったようだ。
sen.e: Within the Shinsengumi, with many of its members being expert swordsmen, Genzaburo's skill was inconspicuous; however, he was very aware of his position and performed his duties without fail.
Within the Shinsengumi, with many of its members being expert swordsmen, Genzaburo's skill was inconspicuous; however, he was very aware of his position and performed his duties without fail.
Within the Shinsengumi, with many of its members being expert swordsmen, Genzaburo's skill was inconspicuous; however, he was very aware of his position and performed his duties without fail.

sen.j: 慶応元年6月の組織再編成で六番隊組長に任じられる。
sen.e: In June of 1865, he was appointed the leader of the 6th group in restructuring of the Shinsengumi.
In June of 1865, he was appointed the leader of the 6th group in restructuring of the Shinsengumi.
In July of 1865, he was appointed the leader of the 6th group in restructuring of the Shinsengumi.

sen.j: 慶応3年6月、新選組総員は幕府直参に取り立てられるが、その際源三郎は副長助勤として七十俵三人扶持を与えられる。
sen.e: In June 1867, all members of the Shinsengumi were called into service directly under the Bakufu and, as a Fukucho jokin (assistant vice commander), Genjiro was given 70 bales of rice, an annual "three-man" rice stipend.
sen.cmt: 七十俵三人扶持の意味が不明です。
sen.e: In June 1867, all members of the Shinsengumi were called into service directly under the Bakufu and, as a Fukucho jokin (assistant vice commander), Genjiro was given 70 bales of rice, an annual "three-man" rice stipend.

In July 1867, all members of the Shinsengumi were called into service directly under the Bakufu and, as a Fukucho jokin (assistant vice commander), Genjiro was given 70 bales of rice, an annual "three-man" rice stipend.

sen.j: しかしその後の幕末政局は、大政奉還、王政復古 (日本)の大号令と続き、佐幕派の新選組に属する源三郎らは劣勢に立たされていく。
sen.e: However, the Bakufu government was subject to the Taisei Hokan (transfer of power back to the Emperor) and Declaration of the Restoration of Imperial Rule, and Genzaburo and his group in the Sabaku-ha (supporters of the Shogun) section of the Shinsengumi were placed in inferior positions.

However, the Bakufu government was subject to the Taisei Hokan (transfer of power back to the Emperor) and Declaration of the Restoration of Imperial Rule, and Genzaburo and his group in the Sabaku-ha (supporters of the Shogun) section of the Shinsengumi were placed in inferior positions.

However, the Bakufu government was subject to the Taisei Hokan (transfer of power back to the Emperor) and Declaration of the Restoration of Imperial Rule, and Genzaburo and his group in the Sabaku-ha (supporters of the Shogun) section of the Shinsengumi were placed in inferior positions.

sen.j: 慶応4年1月、鳥羽・伏見の戦いが勃発する。
sen.e: In January 1868, the Battle of Toba-Fushimi broke out.
In January 1868, the Battle of Toba-Fushimi broke out.
In January 1868, the Battle of Toba-Fushimi broke out.

sen.j: 新選組は伏見に屯所を移していたが、淀まで退却。
sen.e: The Shinsengumi had its quarters transferred to Fushimi at the time; however, it was forced to retreat to Yodo.
The Shinsengumi had its quarters transferred to Fushimi at the time; however, it was forced to retreat to Yodo.
The Shinsengumi had its quarters transferred to Fushimi at the time; however, it was forced to retreat to Yodo.

sen.j: 1月5日、淀千両松で新選組は官軍と激戦（淀千両松の戦い）。
sen.e: January 5, the Shinsengumi fought in a fierce engagement with government troops at Yodo-Senryomatsu (Battle of Yodo-Senryomatsu).
January 5, the Shinsengumi fought in a fierce engagement with government troops at Yodo-Senryomatsu (Battle of Yodo-Senryomatsu).
January 29, the Shinsengumi fought in a fierce engagement with government troops at Yodo-Senryomatsu (Battle of Yodo-Senryomatsu).

sen.j: その戦いの最中、敵の銃弾を腹部に受けて戦死した。
sen.e: During the war, he was shot on his stomach and died.
During the war, he was shot in his stomach and died.
During the war, he was shot in his stomach and died.

sen.j: 享年40。
sen.e: He was 40 years old.
He was 40 years old.
He was 40 years old.

sen.j: 甥である井上泰助が源三郎の首を持ち帰ろうとした。
sen.e: There is a story told that Genzaburo's nephew, Taisuke INOUE tried to take his head home.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: There is a story told that Genzaburo's nephew, Taisuke INOUE tried to take his head home.
There is a story told that Genzaburo's nephew, Taisuke INOUE tried to take his head home.

sen.j: あまりの重さのために仲間の隊士から諭されて、戦場の近くの寺院の境内に源三郎の首を埋葬したというエピソードが伝わっている
sen.e: It was so heavy, though, that others suggested it be buried in the temple near the battleground.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It was so heavy, though, that others suggested it be buried in the temple near the battleground.
It was so heavy, though, that others suggested it be buried in the temple near the battleground.

sen.j: その他
sen.e: Other
Other
Other

sen.j: 首と刀は甥の井上泰助が近くの寺院に埋めたとされるが、いまだに正確な場所は不明である。
sen.e: Genzaburo's head and sword were said to have been buried in the nearby temple by his nephew, Taisuke INOUE; however, the exact location is unknown.
Genzaburo's head and sword were said to have been buried in the nearby temple by his nephew, Taisuke INOUE; however, the exact location is unknown.
Genzaburo's head and sword were said to have been buried in the nearby temple by his nephew, Taisuke INOUE; however, the exact location is unknown.

sen.j: なお、墓所は日野市の宝泉寺 (日野市)となっている。
sen.e: His grave is at Hosen-ji Temple in Hino City.
His grave is at Hosen-ji Temple in Hino City.
His grave is at Hosen-ji Temple in Hino City.

sen.j: 淀千両松→淀城間、京都・宇治に欣浄寺（ごんじょうじ）という廃寺が当時存在したが、明治頭には取り壊されてしまった。
sen.e: The grounds of a temple named Gonjo-ji Temple are located in Uji, Kyoto, somewhere between Yodo-Senryomatsu and Yodo Castle, which was demolished at the beginning of Meiji period.
The grounds of a temple named Gonjo-ji Temple are located in Uji, Kyoto, somewhere between Yodo-Senryomatsu and Yodo Castle, which was demolished at the beginning of Meiji period.
The grounds of a temple named Gonjo-ji Temple are located in Uji, Kyoto, somewhere between Yodo-Senryomatsu and Yodo-jo Castle, which was demolished at the beginning of Meiji period.

sen.j: 井上生家の隣にも欣浄寺という全く同じ名称の寺が存在するため、埋葬場所はこの廃寺であった可能性が高い。
sen.e: There is a temple with the same name, Konjo-ji, next to Inoue's birthplace, making it highly possible that his burial ground is this demolished temple.
There is a temple with the same name, Konjo-ji, next to Inoue's birthplace, making it highly possible that his burial ground is this demolished temple.
There is a temple with the same name, Konjo-ji, next to Inoue's birthplace, making it highly possible that his burial ground is this demolished temple.
